metadata./Keywords: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma; Bowel obstruction; Volvulus; Neonate; Pediatric surgery
metadata./Title: Abdominal kaposiform hemangioendothelioma presenting as volvulus and recurring intestinal obstruction in a neonate: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma is a rare vascular tumor primarily occurring in infants and children. 
The most common sites for kaposiform hemangioendothelioma are extremities, with very few cases of abdominal 
kaposiform hemangioendothelioma reported in neonates. Making a diagnosis of Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma 
can be challenging when the patient presents with generalized symptoms such as bilious vomiting and constipation 
that can be attributed to other more common causes of intestinal obstruction.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 28-day-old Pakistani baby girl presented with bilious vomiting and constipation. The abdomen 
was distended, and scans showed generalized dilation of bowel loops. A preliminary diagnosis of intestinal obstruction due to volvulus was made, and the patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy. Postoperatively, the patient 
remained unwell with profuse aspirates in nasogastric and no improvement in ileus. Repeat scans were again suggestive of midgut volvulus, which was initially managed conservatively, but later redo surgery was done. Ischemic bowel 
was resected with histopathology showing kaposiform hemangioendothelioma. In the meantime, the baby developed an abdominal collection, infection, and short gut syndrome due to resection of the bowel. The family was counseled regarding the prognosis, and the patient was transferred from hospital to home upon request. The baby passed 
away 2 days later.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion While extremely rare, abdominal kaposiform hemangioendothelioma can be an important and potentially lifesaving differential diagnosis to consider in neonates and infants with recurring and nonresolving intestinal 
obstruction. The management is complex, and prognosis can be poor in diffuse, congested lesions involving a large 
part of the gut.
Keywords  Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma, Bowel obstruction, Volvulus, Neonate, Pediatric surgeryOpen Access

salaar.ahmed@scholar.aku.edu

Page 2 of 6 Ahmed et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:619 
Background
Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma (KHE) is a rare 
tumor of the blood vessels found mostly in children 
and infants and can present at various sites throughout 
the body [1]. Fewer than ten cases of abdominal KHE 
have ever been reported. Here, we discuss the case of a 
28-day-old girl who presented with bilious vomiting and 
constipation, common signs of intestinal obstruction due 
to volvulus, and was managed on the same lines. It was 
after recurrent episodes of obstruction and sequelae of 
KHE that the diagnosis was made. We also later discuss 
potential treatment options for such cases.
Case presentation
A 28-day-old baby girl of Pakistani origin, born fullterm at 38+ weeks to a gravida 2, para 1 (G2P1) mother 
via elective lower segment cesarian section (LSCS), was 
brought to the emergency room on 2 July with the com plaint of vomiting during the last 9 days. Initially, the epi sodes only happened after feeding, and the vomitus was 
yellow, nonprojectile, and nonbilious; however, in the 
previous 4 days, it had become bilious, projectile, and 
profuse, occurring every 30 minutes. The baby had also 
developed constipation and had not passed stools for 5 
days but was passing flatus freely.
Initially, the child was admitted to a local hospital, 
600 km away from our center, where a Gastrografin study 
(on 30 June) showed dilated gut loops and delayed stom ach emptying (> 7 hour). They were referred to our hos pital with suspicion of intestinal obstruction. On arrival, 
the child was active (Glasgow Comma Scale 15/15) and 
afebrile, with blood pressure (BP) of 97/53, pulse of 149, 
 SpO2 of 96%, respiratory rate of 46, and blood glucose of 
96. Respiratory and precordial examinations were unre markable. The abdomen was distended but soft, with no 
visceromegaly or guarding and audible gut sounds.
Pediatric surgery was consulted with suspicion of 
intestinal obstruction due to malrotation and volvu lus. Initial labs were ordered (including complete blood 
count, C-reactive protein, electrolytes, clotting pro file, creatinine, X-ray abdomen, and ultrasound), and 
intravenous fluids with antibiotics (ceftriaxone plus 
amikacin) were started. A yellow aspirate was obtained 
from the nasogastric (NG) tube, and an X-ray showed 
generalized dilation of bowel loops with no pneumop eritoneum (Fig.  1). Ultrasound of the abdomen showed 
normal orientation of the superior mesenteric artery 
(SMA) and superior mesenteric vein (SMV). However, 
the contrast esophagogram showed significantly redun dant and dilated duodenum and proximal jejunum, rel atively higher cecum resulting in the short mesentery, 
and decompressed distal jejunum and ileum, probably representing partial obstruction, secondary to short 
mesentery or Ladd’s bands.
The baby underwent an exploratory laparotomy 
and resection of Ladd’s bands. Intraoperative findings 
included dilated loops of ileum and collapsed jejunum, 
with internal herniation of jejunal loops. Ladd’s bands 
were noted and removed, malformation corrected, and 
inverted appendectomy done. Diffuse mesenteric con gestion was noted, but there was no demarcated lesion 
in the explored bowel.
Post surgery, the baby was shifted to the neonatal 
intensive care unit (NICU), intubated, and kept sedated 
on intravenous morphine. The condition of the patient 
initially improved, and feeding was started after 3 days 
of surgery. However, in the following days, copious 
amounts of yellow aspirates kept coming into the NG 
tube with persistent bowel distension on serial X-rays, 
and therefore, the patient was put on nil by mouth 
(NPO) again. Scanty stools were being passed. C-reac tive protein levels were elevated (to 154) and blood cul tures were drawn showing carbapenemase-producing 
Klebsiella pneumoniae, for which colistin was added. 
Repeat upper gastrointestinal (GI) studies showed mid gut volvulus with dilation of bowel loops (Fig.  2), which 
was initially conservatively managed with the place ment of a nasoduodenal (ND) tube, omeprazole, dom peridone, and total parenteral nutrition (TPN) due to 
the condition of the patient. However, the patient did 
not respond to conservative management with persis tent aspirates and distension, owing to which the next 
surgery was planned.
Fig. 1 X-ray of abdomen obtained on the day of admission showing 
generalized dilation of bowel loops
Page 3 of 6
 Ahmed et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:619 
 
On 21 July, a redo laparotomy with ischemic bowel 
resection was performed, with resection of a signifi cant portion of the ischemic small bowel (22 cm of the 
jejunum), with end-to-end anastomosis done (Fig.  3). 
Again, diffuse congestion and thickening of shortened 
mesentery were noted surrounding edematous bowel 
walls. There were dusky adhesions between loops of 
proximal and distal jejunum. This time, a sample was 
obtained for histopathological evaluation.
Postoperatively, the patient became hypotensive (54–
90/33–64) and tachycardic (138–200), with elevated 
white blood cell (WBC) count. A preliminary diagno sis of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) 
was made, and the patient was managed on inotropes. 
Tracheal aspirates showed heavy growth of carbap enem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE), for which 
intravenous antibiotics were continued. The baby was 
kept on TPN and strict NPO owing to the expected 
short gut syndrome post resection. Over the follow ing week, the condition of the patient improved, and 
the patient was extubated on high flow nasal cannula 
(HFNC), and later on room air, with improving vitals 
suggestive of resolving SIRS. However, gut dysmotil ity persisted with bowel dilation, again seen on serial 
X-rays.Histopathology reports came back showing nodules 
and tufts of spindle-shaped tumor cells infiltrating the 
wall of the intestine. These tumor cells were arranged 
in a swirling growth pattern which formed glomeruloid 
structures, highly suggestive of kaposiform hemangioen dothelioma (Fig.  4). Considering the diagnosis, computed 
tomography (CT) angiography with contrast was per formed the next day. It showed hepatomegaly with a large 
intraperitoneal fluid collection showing air–fluid levels 
extending to the pelvis, measuring 75 × 18 × 38  mm3 on 
CC, TR, and AP , corresponding to 25 cc (Fig. 5). No obvi ous arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) or vascularity 
were noted (Fig.  6). Over the next week, the abdominal 
distension worsened, with labs showing a marked drop 
in hemoglobin (to 7.1) and progressive thrombocytope nia (< 50,000), with hypofibrogenemia (98), indicative 
of Kasabach–Merrit syndrome. Follow-up ultrasounds 
suggested an interval increase in the volume of localized 
fluid collection, now corresponding to 59 cc, significantly 
compressing the bowel loops.
Later, a multidisciplinary team (MDT) comprising 
members from general pediatrics, pediatric surgery, 
oncology, gastroenterology, and radiology was formu lated and held its first meeting, reviewed the histopa thology report and clinical condition of the infant, and 
decided to start propranolol with steroids and insert a 
pigtail catheter to drain the abdominal collection. An 
ultrasound-guided catheter placement was performed 
Fig. 2 Contrast study showing a typical corkscrew appearance 
of the duodenum with right-sided duodenojejunal flexure suggestive 
of midgut volvulus
Fig. 3 Resected portion of the ischemic small bowel; 22 cm 
of jejunum was resected, subsequently leading to short gut 
syndrome
Page 4 of 6 Ahmed et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:619 
on the same day, and 20  cc of thick, yellow, pus-like 
fluid was aspirated and sent for culture. Infectious 
disease was consulted, and intravenous piperacillin 
tazobactam, erythromycin, and amphotericin B were 
continued.
Over the next week, the patient’s condition further 
deteriorated. Upper GI studies again showed dilated 
distal duodenal loops with a delay in contrast passage. 
The family was counseled regarding the prognosis and 
the possibility of an intestinal transplant in Pakistan. 
The code was changed to do not resuscitate (DNR) on 
the family’s request, the pigtail catheter was removed, 
and the patient switched to comfort care on TPN. The 
family requested that the patient be transferred to her 
home city, which the hospital had arranged, and the 
patient was discharged on the 53rd day of admission. 
The patient passed away 2 days later at home.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma (KHE) is a 
rare tumor of the blood vessels, primarily occur ring in infants and children [1]. It is classified to be of 
Fig. 4 Histopathology images show typical glomeruloid structures 
and nodules of tumor, infiltrating the smooth muscle wall 
of the intestine and ectatic vessels at the periphery of nodules (top), 
with high-power view showing slit-like vascular lumina and tuft 
of capillary-sized vessels and spindle cells (bottom)
Fig. 5 Computed tomography of abdomen shows a large 
intraperitoneal fluid collection, with air-fluid level and extending 
into the pelvis, measuring 75 × 18 × 38  mm3 in craniocaudal (CC), 
transverse (TR), and anteroposterior (AP) dimensions corresponding 
to a volume of 25 cc
Fig. 6 Computed tomography angiography of the patient showing 
mild hepatomegaly with no obvious arteriovenous malformation, 
opacifications, or aneurysmal dilations. Small patent ductus arteriosus 
(PDA) and patent foramen ovale (PFO) were noted
Page 5 of 6
 Ahmed et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:619 
 
intermediate malignant potential, according to the World 
Health Organization (WHO) classification of soft tissue 
tumors. It therefore is thought to be a borderline malig nant entity between a benign hemangioma and a highly 
malignant angiosarcoma [2]. With an estimated inci dence of 0.07 per 100,000 cases per year, KHE is a wellknown yet poorly understood clinical entity carrying 
high mortality rates (20–30%) owing to its local aggres siveness, inoperability (when close to vital visceral struc tures), and Kasabach–Merritt syndrome [3, 4].
Similarly, KHE is known to have a predilection for 
affecting extremities, often presenting as superficial or 
deep extremity masses [5]. Rarely, it can affect the lungs, 
scrotum, tongue, and abdomen, as seen in this patient 
[6–8].
For any neonate presenting with profuse vomiting and 
constipation, alongside a radiological picture as seen in 
our case, with generalized dilation of bowel loops with 
no detectable masses, intestinal obstruction due to mal rotation and volvulus is the primary and most important 
differential in almost every case. The Gastrografin study 
performed at the previous center and the contrast esoph agogram performed at our center were also suggestive 
of the same etiology. The first surgery was performed as 
part of the standard protocol of the center, with a sus picion of bowel obstruction secondary to malrotation 
and volvulus. The congestion and thickening of mesen tery were initially ignored as sequelae of acute intestinal 
obstruction, which has been observed in the literature.
It is important to recognize that histopathology 
remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of this dis ease with classical cluster of differentiation (CD) 31 and 
CD34 positivity on immunohistochemistry [5]. Multiple 
radiological studies including ultrasonography and CT 
scan failed to detect a lesion in our patient, and it was 
in fact the operative findings in the redo surgery that 
raised the concern of a diffuse vascular pathology. While 
intestinal KHE is a rare entity, with fewer than ten cases 
ever reported in neonates, it must be a differential con sidered in neonatal intestinal obstruction in the presence 
of a well- or ill-defined vascular lesion in the gut wall. 
Diagnosis in our case was even more challenging owing 
to the absence of such a clear lesion and more diffusely 
increased vascularity.
Therefore, while surgical management can be cura tive in cases of well-demarcated vascular lesions in the 
gut wall, in more diffuse or widespread disease, a com bination of medical therapy with steroids and interferons 
with or without surgery is often preferred [9, 10]. In our 
case, propranolol was also added at the suggestion of an 
oncologist on the MDT. Propranolol is a nonselective 
β-adrenergic receptor blocker. It is effective in managing 
infantile hemangiomas and to a lesser degree in infantile kaposiform hemangioendothelioma by inducing vaso constriction and downregulating growth factors [11–13].
As the condition of the patient further deteriorated, 
she developed Kasabach–Merritt syndrome, a relatively 
specific and feared complication of KHE, associated with 
high mortality rates, reported to be as high as 50% [14]. 
This type of consumption coagulopathy is associated 
with fast-growing large vascular lesions, most commonly 
in abdominal and mediastinal KHEs such as in our case. 
The first line of management is steroids and supportive 
therapy, both of which were being given to the baby [14]. 
The patient was also administered 1 unit of cryoprecipi tate, 2 units of irradiated RBCs initially, and another unit 
of irradiated RBCs before discharge; all of these decisions 
are supported in previous literature [15, 16].
The parents of the patient were extensively counseled 
throughout her stay at the hospital, including regarding 
the prognosis, the need for intestinal transplantation, 
a service that is not available in Pakistan, as well as the 
palliative and comfort care of the patient during transfer 
and at home. Owing to the patient’s complex needs dur ing her hospital stay, a team-based approach was devised 
to delegate care to both general pediatrics and pediatric 
surgery teams. Later, an MDT was set up to provide help 
to primary physicians through a more holistic approach 
to understanding the extent and severity of disease (with 
a radiologist), and provision of adequate and appropriate 
care (with the help of pediatric oncology and gastroen terology). While unfortunately not in this patient’s case, 
MDTs in general have shown to be extremely beneficial 
in improving outcomes for complex multidisciplinary 
care [17, 18]. It should also be considered that this case 
report in no way is representative of any set standards 
in the management of abdominal KHE in neonates and 
instead discusses a challenging case of multidisciplinary 
care.
Conclusion
While extremely rare, abdominal KHE can be an impor tant and potentially lifesaving differential diagnosis to 
consider in cases of recurring and nonresolving intestinal 
obstruction in neonates and infants. While it can present 
as a well-demarcated lesion in some cases, other lesions 
can be more diffuse and congestive, making them diffi cult to identify via scans and intraoperatively. Histopa thology remains the gold standard for confirmation of 
diagnosis, and once diagnosed, an MDT should manage 
the complex medical needs of such patients holistically.
Abbreviations
KHE  Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma
NG  Nasogastric
LSCS  Lower segment cesarian section
SMA  Superior mesenteric artery
SMV  Superior mesenteric vein
Page 6 of 6 Ahmed et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:619 
NICU  Neonatal intensive care unit
NPO  Nothing by mouth
TPN  Total parenteral nutrition
AVM  Arteriovenous malformation
DNR  Do not resuscitate
SIRS  Systemic inflammatory response syndrome
MDT  Multidisciplinary team
HFNC  High-flow nasal cannula
GI  Gastrointestinal

manuscript.

Declarations
Ethics approval and consent to participate
The article is a case report; therefore, no approval was required from the Ethics 
Review Board (ERB) at Aga Khan University. Formal approval was obtained 
from the Departmental Review Committee.
Consent for publication
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient’s legal guardian for 
publication of this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the 
written consent is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal
Competing interests
The authors of the study have no financial or nonfinancial competing interests 
to declare.
